content.description:
Begin with a fun stem until reaching a small overhang and the crux. Use small footholds to bump higher and eventually reach the large chockstone above, either side is a bomber hold. The chockstone will look iffy but is quite solid. Use that to get past the overhang then grab a handle above but grab it *lightly* because it’s weak.

Two solid bolts are on top and must be extended quite far with webbing, cordelette, or a static line. A 50’ static line worked great for anchoring with a knotted sliding X.
content.location: The start is the same recessed section as the beginning of Hop on the Bus Gus but diverts right pretty quickly. Look for the sport bolts.

content.description: Start with a fun stem. Avoid the choss. Move out left and up. This tends to be the crux. The crux is well protected. 7 bolts, 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: To the right of “Get Yourself Free”.

content.description: The start tends to be the crux. Crimps and some stellar hands and feet throughout. Really fun movements. Chossy at the top. Pull down, not out. Finish with some sandy slopers. Accessible via the left most top rope anchor. Use a quad and one quickdraw in the redirect bolt. Looking at the crag, access the top from a short scramble up to the right. Watch out for the crypto.
content.location: To the left of “Hop on the Bus Gus”. Uses the right redirect bolt, also to the right of the left most top rope anchor.

content.description: The crux is at the start mainly, but towards the top there is another difficult move. A very edgy crimpey climb will make your fingers sore, but you can use the arete on the left to help. Feels a lot like a really fun highball bouldering problem, but would need several crash pads because of uneven ground. Protected with great bolts for the anchor and another for the directional, although the anchor bolts are spaced a little weirdly so probably use something like a sliding X to equalize. Also ideal to use some cordelette to throw the anchor over the edge, friction is otherwise bad really quick on the pretty chossy top edge.
content.location: See the main photo of the area, it’s marked. It’s the leftmost climb, directly underneath the left directional bolt.

content.description: This is my favorite climb at the crag. Super fun. I layback on this bad boi all day. Others like to shove their body into the void. Do what feels right.
content.protection: 2 bolt anchor. Top Rope this thing. Has yet to be climbed with a trad rack, it can be done. It’s choosy in there.
content.location: This route can be accessed by scrambling up to the right from the main crag. The same way you would go if you were to set up top ropes for the routes near hop on the bus Gus. It’ll be to the right once you get on top. Look for a large pillar, its not separated. The route will be to the left side of the pillar. To set up a top rope you will need to continue scrambling to the left of the climb. Once on top get above the route. There is a rock and a single bolt that you can rappel off of to set up on the two bolt anchor for the route. It may be helpful to bring an extra rope.
